subNodes.conversationText: root
We should get this over with as quickly as possible.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::1    |
I still can't believe Manfred is dead, <FirstName>.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::10    ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::15    |
I know, Vroman, I know.  Why don't you tell me more about him?  Perhaps it will ease your mind.|***ga_global_int-->String::sympathetic    String::++    |

He was always the good one--kept to his books, kept his lofty ambitions within the realm of possibility.  I was always getting into trouble and never really had any ambitions beyond the next night's coin or capers.|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_inf    String::++    |
His death was brutal and sudden.  We will pay back his foes in kind.
I hope so, and yet I am not sure what Manfred would want.  His ways were always slightly mysterious to me.
Well, believe you must.|***ga_global_int-->String::abrasive    String::++    |
Perhaps so, perhaps so.  You're not one to mince words, are you?|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_inf    String::0    |
[Vroman's eyes begin to tear up.] I suppose we should be going.
Yes.  I am sorry, I can see that this conversation troubles you.|***ga_global_int-->String::sympathetic    String::++    |
If you wish.
[Nod.] I know it's hard. We will do what we can.
Though he appears cheerful, Vroman isn't as voluble as normal.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::10 ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::15 |

The paladin's intrigue with a mercenary, the fall of Darkhold--I can't wait to see Hamfast's face back in Drawn Swords...Nothing to make sense of Manfred's murder, though. |***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::20    |
I am looking forward to Madame Bairnson's pheasant soup.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::25    |

You know, , I've been thinking--Well--[Looking more nervous than usual]--I've been thinking that, of all the people that I've known, I'm glad it was you who was with me when I found out about Manfred.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::30 ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::35 ***gc_check_race_pc-->NOT::True String::1 ***gc_check_race_pc-->NOT::True String::3 ***gc_check_race_pc-->NOT::True String::5 ***gc_check_race_pc-->NOT::True String::6 ***gc_is_female-->NOT::False ***gc_global_int-->NOT::True String::vroman_inf String::0 |
Why is that, Vroman?
It's just that--Well--

We've known each other for a year--which isn't that long, really, but is long enough for a man to know how he feels about a woman. You know that I've always admired you; but I hope you are not too severe on me when I say that I think I might feel that which is beyond admiration.
This is a lot to handle all at once.  I don't know what to say.
I'm sorry--I probably shouldn't have said anything.  But my heart has been rubbed so raw recently--all of this upheaval, you understand!--that I have no choice but to use my sleeve as a bandage.
If it is not too bold of me to ask, I hope to learn if you could ever entertain feelings for me, or if it is outside the realm of possibility.
I could, yes.
Oh, that gives me hope, that gives me hope!  I would take your hand in mine now if circumstance didn't make it seem premature.
I do not mind.
[Vroman takes your hand in his for a moment, but then gives it back to you.] I do not want to rush things too much, .
Let us continue on our way.
|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_romance    String::++    |
Yes, Vroman, please wait.  I must have time.|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_romance    String::5    |
Of course, of course.  I do not want to rush things between us.
No, Vroman, I am sorry--but I cannot.
You have let me down gently, Mistress.  For that I am grateful.  But I suppose we should get back to whatever we were doing.  Never mind my heart!
I honestly cannot say, Vroman.  This has happened so suddenly.
Nothing you could say or do would make me have any interest in you.
[Blushing.] Oh, Vroman! I need some time to think this over.
I feel much the same way for you.
I am glad to have been here for you.
It warms my heart to hear you say so.
[Shrug.] I have no idea why that might be.
[Shaking his head.] You can be so cold sometimes, . Ah, I am sorry I brought it up.
|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_romance    String::0    |

The Backlands is a far cry from what I'm used to.  Neverwinter, Waterdeep, even good old Berdusk--life in a city is hard to leave behind for long.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::30    ***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::35    |
I do not agree, Vroman.  I would take fresh air, trees, and bird song over the things of the city any day.
I supposed you might say that.
It's not that I dislike it in the Backlands--indeed, there's something even pleasant about the landscape.  But it's a lonely place.
It doesn't have to be lonely, Vroman. We have each other, after all.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False String::vroman_romance String::1 |
Ah, <FirstName>, it pleases me very much to hear you say so.  Still, I wish we were some place a little less bleak and foggy--a little less like my prospects, in other words.
You're thinking about Manfred, aren't you?  I suppose the land itself must seem tinged with your loss.
Yes, it does.  Bleak, foggy.  I feel similarly about my prospects.
Not that I'm depressed!
In any case, the bleak, foggy landscape calls.  Onward.
I will not argue with that.  But I find the melancholy of landscapes such as this quite beautiful.
I am glad you can find such bleak and foggy views beautiful.  I find them too much like my prospects.
[Shrug.]
I can see that I'm boring you.  Let's move on.
Even though I am more at home in the wilderness, I understand the attraction of the city and why you might miss it.
I tend to agree.  Where are the glitter and hustle of city life out here?
Agreed, agreed! It's the life of the city I miss most--this place has its life too, to be sure--
It is my feeling that each place has its advantages.
Perhaps so, but it's harder for some to see the advantages.
[Shrug.] To each his own.
You do believe me, <FirstName>, when I say that I have no idea what the Cyricist was talking about?|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::40    |

I never doubted you, Vroman.  Please know that I speak from the heart.|***-->***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::1    ***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>1    |

I do, I do.  And yet--How can I be sure?  Too much has happened too suddenly.  I hardly trust myself; I am a rapscallion and a coward, and always have been.  I--I think I need some time to think about things.
Vroman, listen to me.  I trust you; you should trust yourself.
Perhaps so.  And yet there is much cause for doubt in all that has happened recently--
What do you mean?  What "things?"
My brother's death, our adventures here, you and I--Do not take this the wrong way, <FirstName>.  We have known each other for a long time--I simply do not want to make any missteps at this stage.
Let's go.
Fine.  I was only trying to comfort you.
I trust you, Vroman.  You should know that by now.
That means more to me than you know, <FirstName>.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>1    |
I have always looked up to you; I do not think I could handle it if you began looking down on me.
That means much, <FirstName>.
I have no reason either to believe or to disbelieve you.
I wish I could think with as much calmness and balance as you, <FirstName>.  Still, I hope that our friendship is durable enough to weather that madman's declaration.
I am not a fool; I trust only myself.

That hurts, especially coming from you, <FirstName>.  Do not let that fool's crazy declaration come between us.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::1    ***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>1    |
By Tymora, don't let this come between us. I know that you are--independent--but that doesn't mean that I deserve mistrust or indifference.
It matters little to me.

I am astounded; this is all so hard to take.  I am overjoyed that my brother is alive, of course--but it seems strange that we could not spend more time together.  And it upsets me that I do not know Manfred half so well as I thought.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::50    ***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::0    |
Manfred seems to have had good reason to keep his survival secret.  I am sure the two of you will have the chance to talk things over soon enough.
Yes, I know.  He's a Harper and all that--and I suppose you will be, too, soon enough?
I have entertained the possibility.
In my opinion, you are meant for them; I only wish that they'd asked me, too, though I suppose their ways are a little too obscure and noble for a lowly rogue like me. Ah well.
Let's keep moving.
Without a doubt.
Perhaps.
I have no intention to join those schemers.
Truly?  That surprises me.
It does seem as if Manfred could have spent more time with you before he left, but it's also true that the circumstances of your reunion were not kind.

I'm glad you see it the same way, but also with some perspective. Manfred, a Harper! And pursued by an unknown enemy! It is all so much to take--and I suppose you are going to join the ranks of Those Who Harp soon enough, eh?
[Shrug.] It's certainly not my concern.|***ga_global_int-->String::abrasive String::++ |
Then I wonder why I even brought it up.  Let's go.

I am astounded; this is all so hard to take. I am overjoyed that my brother is alive, of course--but it seems strange that we could not spend more time together. It upsets me that I do not know Manfred half so well as I thought. [Skeptically.] I wonder--do I know you, my dear?|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::50 ***gc_global_int-->NOT::False String::vroman_romance String::1 |
First you complain about not knowing yourself; now you complain about not knowing me. If you are so full of doubt, I do not see how you could possibly trust anything, including your feelings.
I understand how you feel, <FirstName>.  As I've said before, though, I need time to sort things out.  The fact that Manfred now lives hasn't changed that--if anything, it's made it more clear to me.
[Trying to jest, but speaking with a slight bitterness.] And I suppose that you are to join the Harpers now?
What do you mean, Vroman?  You know that I feel deeply for you.  Isn't that enough?
Yes--and no.
Your inability to trust anything tires me.
I am sure that it does. It tires me, too.

I am astounded; this is all so hard to take.  I am overjoyed that my brother is alive, of course--but it seems strange that we could not spend more time together.  It upsets me that I do not know Manfred half so well as I thought.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::50    ***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>1    |

I hope that I know you better than I seem to know him; although I think there is still something about you I don't know. How you feel about me, to put it succinctly. Could you...entertain feelings for me, Milady?
That is a question I am still asking myself, Vroman.  Please, do not rush me.

Of course, of course.  I see that you still have not decided; that is fine.  I have always been rash in affairs of the heart--it is good that you approach them with more deliberation.  Forgive me; we will speak of this another time.
You have another big decision to make, after all.  Do you think you will join the Harpers?
[Blushing.] Oh, Vroman. This again!
A Harper Friend, eh? Despite sharing the same title, Those Who Harp still seem to have privileged you with information we didn't get.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False String::Q_MANFRED String::55 |
[Clearly jealous.] What were you and Manfred discussing so late into the night, ? Why can you not tell me?|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False String::vroman_romance String::>0 |
Do not be jealous, Vroman!  I assure that you what we were discussing was secret for good reason.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>0    |
I hope so, and yet I cannot be sure.  You must understand, <FirstName>, that when I am not robbing or romancing I live in a state of perpetual doubt.
I understand well enough, Vroman.  It is one of your most charming qualities.
I am glad to hear you say so.  It is part and parcel of who I am, so I have no choice in the matter.  In any case--
I wish I understood that tendency of yours better.  It is far from endearing.
Do you think so, <FirstName>?  It is, unfortunately, part and parcel of who I am.  I am surprised we have traveled together for so long if the trait is so irksome to you.  In any case--
What you mean to say, Vroman, is that you live in a state of perpetual selfishness--whether robbing, romancing, or doing neither.
[Slyly.] Ah, I fear you are right. Constant doubting is only a sophisticated form of egoism. In any case--
That's interesting, but we must be off.
I wish I could tell you, Vroman. You must know, though, that your brother and I have very good reasons for keeping the information secret--for now.
I am sorry, Vroman, but I cannot divulge any of that to you.
Mind your own business.|***ga_global_int-->String::abrasive    String::++    |
That stings, Milady.  That stings.  Fine.  Let us be on our way.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::>0    |
It saddens me that the business of my companion and the business of my brother are not my business, too. Ah well. Let us do whatever it is we need to do--I will simply follow blindly.
I suppose you still won't tell me what you and Manfred were discussing last night.

So you are now a Harper.  It follows, I suppose.  And with the new title comes new privileges--being a party to mysteries and manipulations, keeping secrets...|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::60    |

Let us go check on the priest.  I know Manfred lives, but I still feel a great deal of affection for him; he was very kind to me.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::65    |

Gods!  This is all so grisly.  I fear that this Harper business is beginning to have too much of an impact on Drawn Swords.  Let us speak more after we get to the bottom of this.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::70    |
I feel as if we are reaching the adventure's denouement, <FirstName>.|***gc_journal_entry-->NOT::False    String::Q_MANFRED    String::>70    |
I wonder--What will become of us once this is all over? I know that I have been far from ideal as far as being a lover goes--|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False String::vroman_romance String::>0 |
But you must forgive me for my distance.  These events have proven to be bigger than the small dramas of the heart.|***gc_global_int-->NOT::False    String::vroman_romance    String::1    |
You speak of your own heart, Vroman, but have little regard for mine.  I have come to expect that this is typical of you.
So be it.  I hope you can still cherish me as a friend.|***ga_global_int-->String::vroman_romance    String::0    |
Yes, Vroman.  You need a friend more than you need a beloved, I think.
Perhaps so, <FirstName>.  Perhaps...we should not speak of this again, at least any time soon.  I am sorry for all the confusion; but now bigger things call.  Onward.
We will see.  For now, there are other things that demand our attention.
Of course.  Onward.
A fellow-adventurer, maybe.  But even friendship will be difficult between us.
After this is all over, Vroman, we can sort out exactly what our relationship is to be. For now--[Grasp Vroman's hand]--We have this.
[Vroman seems taken aback, but his hand closes on yours firmly.] As I've always said, , you're the strong one. I am grateful and honored that you have such faith in me.
But now--adventure calls!  May Tymora will that we have many days ahead of us--together.
There is no drama greater than the heart's.  I wish you understood this--but I do not think you can.
I do not care, Vroman.  I have given up on you.

But I wonder--Have you made up your mind for good?  Will you have me?  I have entreated you time and time again; can I claim your hand knowing, in truth, that you will return my affections as consistently as I have sought yours?
Yes, Vroman, yes. [Take Vroman's hand.]
I wonder what will become of all of us after this is over.  I hope that our adventures shall continue together.
I have no doubt that they shall.  You have been a good companion and a true friend.

As have you, <FirstName>, as have you.  What would have become of me if I had traveled to Drawn Swords without you in tow?  I certainly wouldn't have had the wherewithal to take on the Zhentarim, never mind all the troubles that have followed.
You could have done it--with the help of Ianth, of course.
[Laughing.] Yes, I wouldn't have gotten far without a stronger sword than mine.
Yes, it's quite likely you would have died.
Who knows what the future will bring?
I am not certain, but it is likely we will perish in the coming battle.
Perhaps, but remind me not to turn to you again when I am seeking hope and comfort!  I have learned that it sometimes takes but the appearance of mirth to prevail over life's greatest misfortunes.
[Shrug.] It is not for us to know.
That is true; it all lies in the will of Tymora, who is most reliable in her unreliability.
Let's talk later.
